Hi my name is Ian and today I am here to review Portal 2.

Portal 2 is a fun platform game that overwhelms you with the artistic features that come with the game, with features such as; shooting portals, going through an elevator and having a robot control you and your actions.

The gameplay is quite fun and addicting. Portal 2 has an excellent performance on any computer. Portal 2 can pretty much run at approximately 150 FPS on the average PC. I use a HP pavilion 15 and I run at least 170 FPS every time I get onto the game. When you alt tab or momentarily switch to another screen, Portal 2 is still on the other side of the screen waiting for you. Which creates no lag input after rejoining into the game.

Portal 2 has a rich and deep story line that follows up to the first game of the Portal series  "Portal". Portal is similar to Portal 2. Except Portal 2 is more like a remastered version with enhanced elements that overall make the game better.

Overall I think Portal 2 is my time favorite strategy game. It is a wonderful game that everyone should try.

I spend in this game 38 hours so i know what write !!!!
Portal 2 is the sequel to the award winning and hugely successful Portal developed by Valve Corporation. It features a single-player story set after the events of Portal's story; and a brand-new Co-op game mode, featuring additional test chambers designed specifically for Co-operative play. 
One reason for its success was innovative game play.  Portal is a puzzle game masquerading as a first-person shooter. The player wields a “portal gun” which creates shortcuts through physical space: Shoot it at a wall and a glowing “portal” appears at the point of impact. Shoot again in a different spot and it makes a second portal. Now the player can walk right through the first portal, and out the second. Think of it as a teleportation gun that requires the player to shoot surfaces to identify the start and end points of their trip.Valve uses this mechanic in complicated puzzles where the player is required to get from one end of the room to another.Players create portals to jump over obstacles, get around barriers, and even crush enemies, teleporting stuff so it falls on top of them.
Gameplay original, scénario intéressant (fait penser au film The Cube).
一款可玩性非常高的游戏

[i] [b] Portal 2 - вторая часть головоломки от первого лица от компании Valve, продолжающая эксперименты над игроком и порталами. Со времен первой части игры прошло много лет, и лаборатория Aperture лежит в руинах. Главная героиня игры, Челл, приходит в себя в одной из многочисленных камер внутри лаборатории, и предпринимает очередную попытку побега из лаборатории, которая заканчивается совершенно не так, как девушка предполагала. Героине предстоит узнать много нового о прошлом компании, познакомиться с совершенно новыми героями и даже помочь старой противнице в ее нелегкой миссии.

Помимо сюжетного режима, Portal 2 может предложить режим кооперативной игры для двоих игроков, в котором главными героями выступают роботы Атлас и Пи-Боди, выполняющие разнообразные поручения GLaDOS. У этих поручений есть отдельная сюжетная линия, которая никак не пересекается с сюжетной линией Челл, и которая ведет к неожиданному окончанию. [/b] [/i]

[h1] Holey moley, v2.0 [/h1]

What differences five years can make! This game is a lot like the original Portal, except more polished and realistic. It has a proper story in it unlike the first one, and the choice of enemies is certainly interesting. I enjoyed sparring with GLaDOS again [spoiler] though Wheatley's betrayal came as a bittersweet surprise. [/spoiler] Learning about Aperture's history was also facinating and added depth to the barebones plot of the first game. 

Gameplay has been expanded and this has been one of the best parts. Yes, the classic gameplay from the first game is still there (and yes, you can still make holes in reality) but to make it more interesting and worth your money (as opposed to say, if you have played the first game you have also played this one) you have more toys to play with. There are hardlight bridges, allowing you to literally walk on sunshine, various gels with various properties, and aerial plates that fling you up in the air, to name a few things. There are more variations in the envionment as you go through the different versions of Aperture Laboratories/Science. In other words, this is not exactly like the first game, and the puzzles are more changeable.

The only gripe I have is the odd placements of the loading screens from time to time. Sure, having loading screens in lifts makes sense, but sometimes you see it right in the middle of walking. That was a little confusing and it kind of broke the 'flow' a little. Still, minor trouble, nothing special.

All in all this sequel takes all the great stuff from the original, and revamps it as well as adds more mechanics to make it interesting. If you loved the first one, like I did, chances are you will love the second one as well.

Инновационный геймплей первой части [b]Portal[/b] принёс игре массовую известность и любовь фанатов, и теперь вторая часть делает то же, что и предшественница, только больше, круче и веселее! Напарников героини теперь двое, появились новые механики, мир Портала выглядит живее, а события разворачиваются стремительнее и масштабнее. А если вспомнить, какой крутой была первая часть, да ещё и прибавить к этому возможность создавать собственные комнаты испытаний, проходить несчётное количество чужих, а также спецальную кампанию для двоих, то получается игра, в которую [u]действительно стоит сыграть каждому[/u], потому что это - пример того, какими должны быть отличные игры.

Portal 2 is the sequel to the classic game portal, both being first person puzzle games. 

The plot of portal 2 is a direct continuation to portal one, so...spoilers. after the end of the first came you are captured and brought back inside the facility, only to be put in stasis. From there, wheatley, a new AI sphere companion, busts you out of your stasis pod and tries to help you escape. From there, shit hits the fan and spirals out of control.

portal 2's gameplay is more or less exactly the same as the last game. The controls do feel a bit smoother than the last one, and the puzzles are alot more difficult than those in the first. However, throughout portal two new mechanics, such as anti gravity machines, gel's and co-op are introduced. There are two campaigns, one meant entirely for solo play, while the other is meant for co-op only and requires another person to actually enjoy. I only experienced the solo campaign, so i will focus on that.

The solo campaign has all the charm the original had and more, everything from the humor to the creativty of the levels is ramped up drastically. While the original game was extremely funny at times, this one keeps that level of comedy constant throughout the campaign from start to finish. The new levels are also extremely satisfying to play through, like before, each level feels like a reward for beating the last, now with added dialog to make you laugh yourself silly. The plot, while relatively simple when you look at it from a objective standpoint, really is a step up when compared to the original, especially when you realize what is at stake. If you also read into some of the smaller details. this relatively dark humor based game becomes genuinely depressing to, such as the actual reason all the characters actually exist in the first place and just how sad those reasons are. Every bit of dialog exists for a reason, every little clue in the game is worth remembering as it will come into play at some point down the line, even the final boss battle requires you to remember one specific bit of dialog from earlier on in order to actually realize "oh, so thats where i should aim".

This all being said, the game is not without its flaws. Several puzzles later on in the game are really annoying, as very important aspects of said puzzle are hidden in obscure corners of the map and i only stumbled upon them by rage scrolling the mouse frantically. The levels in the old part of the labs are great, but there is more visual clutter, which can distract from the elements of the puzzles. While this does not make any of the puzzles extremely difficult, this does cause minor frustration at times.

The game has seen massive amounts of polish though, visually, the game is stunning, even compared to most modern games. The soundtrack is back with a vengence to, unlike the previous game where it was always there and wonderful, but easy to forget about, portal 2 features a much more noticable, distinct soundtrack with a wider variety of tracks that doesn't distract you from the gameplay unless you actually stop and listen. I was even informed by a friend that [spoiler] they deliberately timed how long it would take light to travel from the surface of earth, all the way to the moon in order to accurately depict the time it would take for a portal to form up there. [/spoiler]

Overall, Portal 2 is everything good from portal two, with more polish and greater variety of gameplay. If you were a fan of the original, you will love this. If you found portal one a bit bland but liked the gameplay, portal two improves on the clean cut graphics and adds in more dialog. If you love puzzle games, get this and the original. Even if you don't like puzzle games, there is still something for you as the puzzles aren't mind-bendingly hard but still difficult enough to make you think.

Oh man, this game. 
"RECENT:	Overwhelmingly Positive (874 reviews)
OVERALL:	Overwhelmingly Positive (74,026 reviews)"

That makes perfect sense. There's way too much right with this game, and not enough wrong! It's awesome!

I suppose I'll go into full detail, without trying to spoil it.

In Portal 2, you play as the last game's protagonist, Chell, and, after being reawakened from a state of suspended animation by a small core named Wheatley, you will be put through another series of reality-bending tests by GLaDOS, the last game's antagonist. However, this time around, things get a little more advanced, with new mechanics such as [spoiler] the Propulsion Gel	[/spoiler], [spoiler] Propulsion Gel[/spoiler] and [spoiler] Conversion Gel[/spoiler], as well as another unlikely villain for you to battle.

The concept of the game, for those who've never touched anything in the Portal series, is as follows:
You are in possession of a scientifically engineered tool known as the "Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device™", and are tasked with the key objective of navigating through and completing a series of perplexing tests created by a sentient AI known as the "Genetic Lifeform and Disc Operating System™", or GLaDOS. 

This series is one of the most unbelievably brain-picking, head scratchingly clever and difficult that I've ever had the absolute delight of getting into. The visuals, robotic personalities and Companion Cubes™ are so pleasantly charming, and the humour is actually some of my personal favourites. Compared to the astoundingly astronomical experience that the first game was, this was a massive improvement, and thanks to these improvements, this game is somewhat a completely different experience than the last, with story and character development (GLaDOS and Wheatley, not Chell), the return of the "Aperture Science Weighted Companion Cube™ and puzzles galore, as well as an awesome multiplayer side story, there's plenty to do, and even though I've done it all on PS3, I had to come back and play again here. I've not even finished it yet, due to playing multiplayer for hours with my brother.

PROS:
Puzzles to wrack your brain like never before.
Portal-based conundrums make the game so memorable and fun.
The genius writing for GLaDOS in this game makes for some of the greatest humour of gaming history, In my opinion.
The puzzles are some of the most memorable. Examples include most of the ones you get stuck on for hours at a time.
Being stuck on the puzzles for hours.
Listening to GLaDOS' commentary at the start and end of every chamber.
MULTIPLAYER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Every other thing in the game I haven't mentioned.

CONS:
The puzzles in multiplayer, especially the last few, drove me to check online guides for the answers. That or I'm dim.
The sadness you feel when the game ends. 
Anyone who wants a refund for this game.

Overall, this game, in my personal opinion, gets 10 Aperture Science Weighted Storage Cubes™ out of 10.

Buy this game. You won't regretted. I didn't both times.

Thomas experienced entertainment in a thoroughly conscious™ way. As he nailed his pinky finger, eternally, to the shift key, his eyes glazed over, and he was zapped through a 3D mud world. In this meshy plastic bag world, he was indeed king, and his actions were always the most powerful. He wondered many times what it would be like to completely submit to this world, a world of artificial restraint and power, not beautiful, but secure and unthinking. Sometimes he longed for this, but most of the time thoughts like this dug him another 10 feet deeper into his already monstrous existential nightmare; He knew that when he left the game™, real life would greet him with a pick axe and a 2 ton rock of shit that he would have to mine down until his legs and arms gave way. Of course he would never drive the Fastest and Most Beautiful Cars, or Screw Unsoiled Harlots daily, because in the dirtiest most real truth, he was a chubby fuck up that could only ever continue to ride the garbage cart through the river styx. In 30 years he would either be dead, miserable, or very very high. Oh poor Thomas, reading steam reviews, using the internet, using electronics to power blast your disk-like nipples, beating it to strange pictures because you were bored with mommy's boobs™. You are everyone Thomas, and you should really just take a shower and go for a walk. You aren't Deadpool, you aren't Naruto, you aren't Neil Armstrong, you aren't going to develop anything more than hairy palms and warts on your ass. Great game!

嗯。闲着没事写一篇。
非常经典的解谜游戏啦，剧情什么的做的很棒，虽然前期不知道可以开字幕所以基本没懂。[strike] 被自己蠢哭了qaq	[/strike]然后每一次进出开在地板上的门的时候就会有［我是谁我在哪晚上吃什么］的懵逼感，但是几次过来就适应啦，之前听有人说玩这个会犯3D眩晕，本来挺担心的，但是自己玩了觉得并没有啊，一点都没晕。
单人模式很简单的，不管是走剧情还是创意工坊里的图［基本］都是多想想就可以找到方法的，[strike] 辣种变态难度的就不要说了反正我没玩过哼唧哼唧    [/strike]但是联机就不一样了，难度完全不是1+1级别，特别是玩过有个作者的一个系列，玩到怀疑人生orz。
其实对我来说最重要的是可以和智障朋友们一起玩。[spoiler] 我，我才不会说我全程划水呢哼 [/spoiler]卡关的时候相互吐槽，找到方法就开始吹比，通关的时候站错电梯自己还不知道，说了半天［玛德bug］才突然反应过来是自己的脑子bug了。而且最最重要的是可以互坑啊，当队友站在光桥上，然后自己手一抖就让他掉到水里，或者是在上下两面墙上加速的时候愣是让他多飞一会儿让他飞到懵逼，反正是各种各样的［杀死小伙伴的一百种方法］，自己去探索吧~
BEST GAME EVER its shorter than most megaly sucsesfull games but it is soo fun buy

Amazing master piece. I got fed up with the puzzles in the beginning or middle of the game, but with the epic cinematic chapters that happen every once in a while, I kept going in the game. When it came to the end I felt like all the effortas and brain cells were worth it. Definitely worth the playing and thinking!
Ｔｈｅ ｇａｍｅ＇ｓ ｇｏｔ ｌａｓｅｒｓ ａｎｄ ｌｅｍｏｎｓ ｗｈａｔ ｍｏｒｅ ｃｏｕｌｄ ｙｏｕ ｗａｎｔ ｉｎ ｌｉｆｅ

I'll admit, I'm not one to write positive reviews. It is far easier to rant about something you hate rather than give out glowing praise. The other reason it that I'm not too great at it. However, I abandoned all those foolish notions and am currently tapping my review to the rhythmic sounds of 'Want you gone', humming quietly to myself in my basement, with all the lights off save my computer, in my Wheatley Laboratories hoodie, a turret at my left and my mousepad at my right, not having slept for a longer time than I would care to admit, nearly done with playthrough god-knows-what, five and a half years after this game's release while I listen to the sounds of people telling me Portal is dead slowly fade into the background as I turn up my music. I literally cannot give a higher recommendation. This is my favorite game of all time.

The sheer fact that a main story as short as Portal 2's could manage to give me not only so much playtime, but also the willingness to spend 4 times the game's cost worth of money on merchandise, It really shows just how amazing a game can be. I'm not one to spend money on a whim, either. But this is all besides the point. 

The story is very short, and if there is a drawback, and it has some pacing issues once you know what to do in all the puzzles (that's hardly fair though). I haven't even looked into speedrunning techniques but I can finish the normally 8-12 hour campaign in around two hours simply taking the most direct routes and knowing exactly where to go and what to do when you get there. However while the story itself it relatively short, believe me, it makes up for it in sheer quality. It doesn't have any moving political commentary or complex morals (or any at all, really) and the plot at it's base definitely isn't anything new, but if you're looking at buying this game and somehow have not heard about the beautifully clever and witty dialogue gracing the three or four characters, oh man, you are in for a treat. The best of them by far is Wheatley, with practically every line he says being something you can laugh at (I have an entire folder with about 30 pages of drawings of just him saying some of his more quoteable lines), but every character has their time to shine. GLaDOS has a lot of good stuff in the latter half of the game and I've straight up seen Cave Johnson's "Do you know who I am?! I'm the man whose gonna BURN YOUR HOUSE DOWN! With the LEMONS!" on t-shirts. The writers over at Valve are a seriously gifted bunch, I must say. Portal's dialogue was great, but it does not in any way compare to it's younger brother. Portal 2's plot is actually surprisingly dark once you begin looking deeper into it, especially if you've played the game as much as I have. Spoilers ahead obviously, but you watch Cave Johnson go from a slightly reckless happy scientist to slowly losing finantial support from the government, losing test subjects and employees and finally poisoning himself accidentally with moon rocks, where you hear his dying wishes to put Caroline in charge (who is actually part of GLaDOS now) followed by a 'Good-bye, sir.' from the Caroline in GLaDOS that honestly gets me everytime. Looking into more of Aperture's backstory and revealing how nearly everyone was killed by a rogue GlaDOS, aside from one man who is half going insane and ended up being the one that saved Chell from the fate that claimed all of the other 10-15,000 test subjects holed up in Aperture's relaxation center at the cost of his own life and it ends up weaving this fantastic story where the darkness of what really happened to these characters is hidden within lighthearted and hilarious dialogue that makes the darkness interesting, but never overwhelming. Anything potentially ominious goes with something you can laugh at (see anytime anyone makes a death threat, ESPECIALLY Wheatley) so you never feel weighed down by some of the gravity of the deeper story. I honestly cannot praise it enough. It is something to behold.

Gameplay wise I can't say anything that won't be repeating someone else, but puzzles are highly inventive, never too convoluted or frusterating and all enjoyable and even on your first go, and figuring the game out is very satisfying, even if the level isn't too terribly hard. It has become the game I play to relax, and I love it like a son because of that. The only real issue is far too many of the puzzles are dependent on falling somewhere to launch yourself somewhere else, but to be fair that is a pretty efficient way of getting places sooo... I don't know. I will say though while that is prevelant, it is used in plenty of different ways, so it feels fresh each time it appears.

This was honestly the best 20 bucks I've ever spent, even if it was far, far after the hype had gone. I'd like to say, if the fact this is an older game discourages you from buying, don't let it. I have gotten far more enjoyment out of this than most things I've had in my life, and despite the fact I jumped on a bandwagon that had been abandoned at the side of the road long ago, I don't regret a thing. The dialogue still makes me laugh and the characters are seriously top notch, and I haven't tired of it this far through. That has to be a mark of quality of some sort.
